Robert Blake: Damn, I made a mess out of my life
By COLIN CAMERER
I came out here and won a
contract at MGM in the heyday
of MGM, in the time of Judy
Garland, Spencer Tracy and the
rest of 'em. I started in a thing
called Our Gang. I was Mickey.
With my kids I found the
secret is to not teach 'em but to
learn from 'em. They're born
with everything. And what most
people do is squash it and take it
away from them. If you can just
lay back and trust whatever God
there is in this universe that made
them kids, made 'em to work
that someplace there's more good
in us than bad or we'da never
made it outta the trees in the
first place, we woulda killed each
other in the caves. There's no
such thing as a kid who needs
fixing.
The film "Electra Glide in
Blue" opens with a shot of an
enormous muscle flexing. The
camera pulls back to a full shot
of Robert Blake, in his
underwear, doing chin-ups on a
bar wedged in a doorway. He
drops off the bar, and moves to
the kitchen. While lifting
arm-weights, Blake cracks an egg
into a glass, then drinks it. He
hits the floor and begins doing
push-ups, slowly pumping up and
doWn. He dons a cop uniform,
then goes outside and mounts his
Electra Glide police motorcycle.
He roars away, spitting up dust
and gravel as he disappears down
the long Arizona highway.
An' about my father? He was
pretty sick in the head. As a
matter of fact, if he hadn'ta had
his empire around him, my
mother and three kids, he would've
ended up in the loony bin. But
he had the kind of insanity that
only in my later years I've come
to understand: It was one of the
good things I got. He was a
monster. He beat the shit out of
me from the day I was born, and
my brother, my sister.
In a scene from "Baretta",
Blake hustles out into the street
to apologize to a young woman
reporter who has been covering
an important homicide case, and
knows more about it than
Baretta knows. She is standing
half in the street, angrily trying
to get a cab, Baretta approaches
her: "You can't get no cabs on
dis corner. Lemme give you a
ride, my car's right over here. I
gotta big mouth. I told you what
to do, an' I shouldn't have. My
old man always said, the day
they plants you in the ground
you still got a lot to learn. I was
bad to you, sugar, I'm sorry. I
need your help. I'm a hunnerd
miles behind you, and you're the
best. You're good You stick
with de job, keep doing de job.
You do a great job." Humility
oozes out Blake's fingertips,
compassion steams off his face.
That's a great title. You got
that right on the tee. "There's
Something About Being Straddle
of a Thing." Motorcycles, I love
'ern. I got fucked-up legs from
bikes. I was up on Mulholland
Drive and went right off the
mother. And the last thing I
remember was thinking I gotta.
get away from the bike before we
land or its gonna get me. When I

woke up there was something hot
dripping on my forehead. I had
come about fifty or sixty feet
down and the bike was above me
hung in a tree. And the hot oil
was dripping on my forehead.
And it was like the Lord was
saying, 'Next time I'll let the
bastard drop.' It woulda come
right on top of me and it woulda
been all over.
Elliot Gould and Blake chase
an ambulance in their police car

in a scene from "Busting",
making two-wheeled turns at 70
miles an hour. When tile
ambulance crashes to a halt in a
pile of garbage, a fat mail in a
hospital gown climbs out and
runs down the street. Blake
pursues and catches him, shoving
him mercilessly to the ground.
"We got you, you fucking
pusher! We got you, and your ass
is going up the river!" Blake
screams. The man looks up and
retorts laughingly, "Ha, you
cops, there ain't no court in the
state will hold this up. You know
it, I.know it. You know I own
them all. Ha! You stupid cops. I
gave you your chance to go with
me. You stupid pigs." "Shut up!•
Shut up!"Blake yells. "I'm going
to blow your goddamn melon
away!"
In the first place in television.
here at Universal, nobody listens
and nobody cares. As far as most
people are concer,ned, they just
as soon turn out Perry Mason or
Donald Duck, it don't make no
difference. Cause once you sell
the hour, as long as it's on the
air, it don't matter. You're on
the air or you ain't on the air. It
ain't like a movie, where the
better you make it, the prouder
you are, themore people go to
see it. Or it's like writing a
book-movies, I mean-the more
of your heart you put into it, the
more satisfying it is, the longer
life it has. In television, their
theory is put the money in the
pot; once it's on the air, forget
about it, screw it.
In a second scene from
"Electra Glide", Blake shuffles
into a darkened movie theater,
where an old black janitor is
cleaning up. The janitor looks up,
sees Blake, and keeps sweeping.
The janitor sits down in one of
the seats and takes out a box

lunch. He slowly, very slowly,
unwraps a sandwich and carefully
takes a bite. He chews steadily,
swallows, and then speaks. "You
know, so much of what people
do is just a big framus." Blake
sits down next to him, twisting
his face up into a sighing frown,
etched with despair. Minutes
pass. "Yeah", he says. Then he
gets up and leaves, walking
slowly, careful not to disturb the
janitor's solitude.

thing I learned is this; I am what
I am. I'm crazy, I'm hostile, I got
a lot of drive, I got a lot of hate,
a lot of fear. For most of my life,
I tried to put that away and be
like other people, and therapy
didn't change me.
On the Tonight Show some
months ago, Blake made one of
his many memorable
appearances. After the usual
Carson/Blake banter-Carson
prodding on Blake's disgust with
studio executives-"yeah, them
suits up there in the black tower,
it's an ivory tower too, they
don't care." Then Joyce Brothers
parades out,all set to do battle
with the forces of Personal
Problems. Carson, hunched over,
sporting his patented little-boy
grin, asking questions. Blake
looks on ,half-disgusted, in usual
Blake guise-sweatshirt, cap,
jeans, rumpled hair. Joyce
Brothers suggests satin solutions
to adolescent
problems-"Parents, Johnny,
have to learn to cope with the
problems brought on with the
New Sexuality." Blake suddenly
erupts, pointing and grinding
words-"Yeah, you kids out
there, you gotta hang on. I know
you got problems seem huge
now, you got trouble seems
bigger den life, on account of
you don't know how to deal with

hang in there, don't get tile
heebie-jeebies, it's gonna be
okay." Raw compassion,
incredible vision billowing from
Blake like smoke from a volcano,
or maybe a wild man. Dr. Joyce
Brothers looks singed by the
heat, and resumes her
monologue. Carson looks on.
I finally realized that the
demands I was making were too
big. Too big for the world. Anri

that the world was not at fault,
just one of those things. I was
looking for that kind of love and
that kind of dedication and that
kind of respect that you can only
get from parents.
One day-this is how shrewd
this doctor was and most of 'ern
ain't-he understood to wait his
turn. One day he got up when I
left and walked out of his office
onto this little dirt area. Said, 'I'll
see ya tomorrow.' It was the first

time he ever walked me out. And
I started panicking. He said, 'I'll
see ya tomorrow'. And he put his
arm around my shoulders, and I
cried and I cried and I cried. I
cried for about half an hour,
man, I got snot all over the front
of his jacket. I came totally
apart.
Because if he would have said
to me, Johnny, your problem is
that nobody ever caressed you,
your mother never hugged you,
that's all words. The real secret
of a great doctor or a great
anybody is to make it happen
emotiohally. That's what this guy
did.

wall, in a shot from "In Cold
Blood", wearing the harness used
for hanging victims. His short,
muscular body stands almost
limp with hopelessness, looking
out a window. Raindrops stutter
down the window, and tile light

from outside shines through the
window onto Blake's face,
making it look like he is crying
huge tears. Blake puts on the
Face, compassionate,
understanding yet resigned. His
lips tighten, eyebrows flex, eyes
squinting. "Damn," he says,
"Damn,I made a mess of my life.
I'm sorry. In so really sorry I
can't even say." ile turns to one
of the prison guards-"Man, I
know you gotta take this thing
off and all like that, but could I
please go to de bathroom?"
Yeah, but most of my favorite
actors are dead and in the grave.
But even in the grave they're
more alive than most of us
walking around. John Garfield,
Paul Muni, Charles Laughton,
Claude Rains, Robert Ryan. In
the Pepsi Generation we've
forgotten what real class
is.People inspired each other.
What's around you today is a
bunch of mannequins.
The best work I think I ever
did was the death-house scene by
the window in "In Cold Blood".
That's the one where I think I
got the closest to where I wanted
to go.

Glide': Blake is tooling along on
his bike, the highway stretching
out like a ribbon of time in the
clear sky. Half a mile ahead of
him, something flies out a van's
window As he nears, he sees it is
a wallet. Picking it up, Blake
finds money and some cards-so
he sets off after the van, now
miles ahead of him. As he
approaches, he waves the wallet
and someone in the back of the
van pulls down tile curtains. His
Electra Glide pulls up alongside
the van, Blake still yelling and
waving the wallet. A sawed-off
sho tgun appears in the back
window. As he drifts back behind
the van, he sees the gun just as it
goes off In slow motion, blood
spurt's from his chest, and he
pitches slowly forward onto the
front of the bike. For..several
seconds the camera watches the
motorcycle and its lifeless
passenger. The camera slowly
pulls away, the bike finally
skidding to a halt on the hard
brown road, Blake's body
tumbling off to the side.

want to note:
"We're overwhelmed."
Sociology departments
nationwide, like many other

The Environment of Accounting
Chemists invent a soup
Of chicken molecules, tapped water, and ten minutes.
Powderee chicken broth is dropped into boiling water,
And spreads throughout a whole kitchen
Like an explosion of golden pastel
Among sun lit lint andthinly dusted air.
I breathe in this chalk like chicken
Even before I sit for a bowl.
The noodles, like bony, diving fish
Swerve through the tumbling water.
Chicken molecules, tapped water, and ten minutes?
I am a tourist in a barber chair
With a towel over my face
Unable to taste the many-countried food around me.
My tongue, not languid,
But confused as to the birth of a flavor.
Tables are full of blushed vegetables.
I look for water form deep wells,
Cooled by the walls of the soil.
This water I taste:
A gargled mix of unoiled, emptied juices,
Once milk for a forest deer
refined by shale walls.
The needles that pines set to cushion the ground
Harbor inward waters, nurture ants.
But I hunger for food,
A steaming bowl for dinner,
Soup of chiken cooked clear to the bone.
--Michel Steven Krug
